item.title: Better Off Using Exceptions?
item.description:
I saw this post on error-handling in F‚ôØ, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre better off using Exceptions‚Äù making the rounds on Twitter:

Exception handling is an error management paradigm that has often been met with criticism. Such criticisms typically revolve around scoping considerations, exceptions-as-control-flow abuse or even the assertion that exceptions are really ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Got Mass Affection configured with TLS via LetsEncrypt on GitLab Pages. That was a lot of work. But I‚Äôm glad to have done it; migrating other sites should be easier now that I know what I‚Äôm doing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Nothing like doing a brew upgrade and watching everything on your machine crawl to a stop because you have to recompile gcc. I think I‚Äôll kick that off again next time I‚Äôm out of the house for three hours.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Programming (/life) pro tip: if you can‚Äôt see the value in a pattern someone else finds useful, assume you have something to learn, instead of concluding that the pattern itself is useless.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I was fed up with JIRA, and then I remembered that I have Bee. And I‚Äôm so happy I remembered, because it‚Äôs good.

I recently wrote up some neat things you can do with keyof and mapped types in TypeScript 2.1. In playing further with those bits, I ran into some interesting variations on the approach I outlined there, so here we are.

In the previous post, I concluded with an example ‚Ä¶

item.description:
A thing I just learned: cargo doc --open: full, local docs for every dependency your Rust crate has.

Mind. blown.

item.description: Thanks to everyone who watched Jamon Holmgren and me live-coding in Elm today. Intro to us and to Elm here.

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 2 of 6
item.description: One of my goals for 2016 was to continue writing not only on this blog but in other outlets. I did a *lot* of writing this year, but relatively little of it is published. But here's a look at some of the numbers! (And they are large!)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 1 of 6
item.description: Accidental 20-mile runs, walking pneumonia, gaining weight because of metabolic shifts, and other adventures in my "fitness" in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Introduction
item.description: 2016 was a long, difficult, strange, sometimes wonderful and sometimes dreadful year for me. It was one of the most professionally and scholastically enjoyable and rewarding years of my life, and also one of the most exhausting. As I often do at years-end, I am taking stock publicly of what went well, what went poorly, and what I might do different in a variety of categories!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Things VS Code still needs to fix to be awesome:

  • font-smoothing settings on macOS
  • the color of the status bar
  • ability to cut-to-EOL

And let me turn off the ridiculous smiley-face feedback icon!

To be clear: Code is already very good. But it‚Äôs not quite awesome. (It‚Äôll get ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: The Itch
item.description: Learning functional programming has been simultaneously wildly new and deeply familiar. It's the answer to questions I've been asking for most of a decade.

item.description: Currently almost 7 hours into this work- and school-day, at 2:30pm, and expecting it to be about a 12-hour day. Time to coffee up some more.

item.description: Two lessons from today‚Äôs Rust spelunking: the library team has done a fantastic job, and we need non-lexical, liveness-based lifetimes. (See this discussion by Niko Matsakis for some of the ideas there and why we need them.)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: There‚Äôs nothing like building something real in a language to find all the weird little corners. Even something small will get you there.

item.description: Pro-tip for dealing with HashMaps in Rust: the entry API is often your friend.

item.description: Taking my own medicine :cough:‚ÄîI just submitted a Rust PR documenting RFC #1623. üéâ

item.description: Lots of compilers tell you ‚ÄúFoo is broken!‚Äù I love that both the Rust and Elm compilers try to explain why and how to fix it.

item.description: One of the things I most enjoyed working more on Lightning this weekend: the Rust compiler is so helpful.

item.description: The one upside to tabs (over spaces): they can be whatever visual width you want. (Relevant when, like me, you like a really unusual width. I‚Äôve always been a 3-spaces-wide guy.)

item.title: Using Rust for ‚ÄòScripting‚Äô
item.description: Why I might use Rust instead of Python, with walkthroughs for building a simple "script"-like program and a guide for cross-compiling Rust code to Windows from macOS.

item.title: What is Functional Programming?
item.description: Functional programming‚Äîthough not a panacea‚Äîis a really great tool to have in our toolbelt. (And you don‚Äôt have to be a mathematician to use it.)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Pro tip: use Map and not Object for dictionaries/hash-tables in JavaScript. Performance difference is A LOT. (I haven‚Äôt measured, but for a simple example I was playing with (~12k items) it was at least a couple orders of magnitude.)

Edit: Belay that: the problem was an allocation-speed issue ‚Ä¶

item.description: Front-end web development in one screenshot: macOS Safari on the left, iOS Safari on the right.

item.title: Why Everything is Broken
item.description: It‚Äôs something of a joke among many of the software developers I know to wonder aloud how anything works. We‚Äôre all very painfully aware of how hard it is to write correct code, of how hard it is to account for all the corner cases that will arise ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I‚Äôll go a step further on yesterday‚Äôs comments: I would love to use Reason in a future project.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Using ML-style types to reason through things‚Äîeven just as a reasoning tool, without language support‚Äîmakes such a huge difference.

I‚Äôm rewriting a hairy, often-buggy section of HolyBible.com‚Äôs user logic, and using type definitions for reasoning was invaluable.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Just used LetsEncrypt for the first time.

This is wonderful. ENCRYPT ALL THE THINGS!

And then I set up a cron job to renew it every three months. My maintenance burden for this app just went waaaay down.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Spent a good chunk of the evening working on this static site generator‚Äîby contributing to another library. #opensource software FTW.

item.description: Discovered that Syntect can do highlighting for HTML as well as for editors. More Rust awesomeness.

item.description: It looks my options for HTML templating in Rust are‚Ä¶ quite varied. This is good!

item.description: Curious: I noted during my drive back from vacation today that whenever other conscious thoughts lapsed, my Rust CMS project came to the fore.

item.description: People, React is great‚Äîtruly! But the fact that you only learned about the ideas it uses from React doesn‚Äôt make React itself the paradigm.

A friend in the group responded that he thinks ‚ÄúReact + JS ‚Ä¶

item.description: After two years of using a Garmin 920XT, my considered opinion is: Garmin makes great hardware, and their software is utterly mediocre.

item.description: My kingdom for an IDE with the smarts of JetBrains‚Äô IDEs and a real, non-Java, native UI on macOS.

item.description: I‚Äôm writing a talk on test-driven development with Ember.js for Olo‚Äôs in-house tech talks. How? By building a real feature and capturing the process!

item.description: The latest JetBrains Rider EAP build is pretty fantastic. Nice work, JetBrains.

item.description: I hate JIRA‚Äôs Wiki markup so much. Why in the world they feel the need to stick to that instead of just supporting Markdown, I do not understand.

item.description: Spending my afternoon reading the RELAX NG XML schema language tutorial, so I can implement a parser for it in Rust. Just because, you ask? No, I‚Äôm not that much of a nerd. Suffice it to say that I have ulterior motives.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I‚Äôm quickly discovering a desire for actual, enforceable types as I‚Äôm trying to compose a series of functions. It‚Äôs hard without them.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I‚Äôm so used to dealing with layout distinctly from behavior with the HTML/CSS/JS separation that learning how to lay things out in macOS apps feels weird.

item.description: Fun things in Rust land: the code from the latest episode of New Rustacean, in Raph Levien‚Äôs Xi editor!

item.description: I am trying to fix a bug in a Node.js back end I wrote 18 months ago. And I have never been so tempted in my life to rip out the entire Node back end and replace it with one written in Rust.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Consistency in User Interfaces
item.description:
People sometimes ask what I mean when I say Git‚Äôs UI is maddeningly inconsistent. Here‚Äôs a concrete example: what are the commands to list tags, branches, and stashes?

  • git tag --list
  • git branch --list
  • git stash list

Follow that up by noticing the difference in meaning for the ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Things I did tonight:

  • Keep working on actually building a small app in Swift (not just playing with the language for little things, but starting to learn the macOS frameworks too).
  • Start writing New Rustacean e015.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I really, really prefer codebases which remember that readability matters. Getting everything on one line, at the expense of the line being 234 characters long, is not a win.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Open-source developers who are still using mailing lists for tracking bugs are not on my good list. sigh
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I haven‚Äôt gotten almost anything done today. I think I‚Äôm calling today my day off for this week and I‚Äôll hammer at productive things later.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Wow: a minimal (but extremely useful) lodash install is only 4kb minified and gzipped. I‚Ä¶ need to have this available to use everywhere now, please.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Doing the same little programming task again at regular intervals is a fascinating exercise. Seeing how you‚Äôve learned to tackle the same problem, but better, is illuminating.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I know the Vehicle example is sort of canonical in teaching object-oriented programming. But it‚Äôs wildly disconnected from real software development problems. I don‚Äôt like it.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I‚Äôd love‚Äîlove‚Äîto see an open standard for embedding browser engines (a la Chromium/Electron) emerge, so you can embed whichever you like.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
The build worked on develop last night. We have made no commits. Now it fails.

Current best guess: transitive dependencies. Thanks, npm.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The first thing I do when I start playing with a new language/framework/etc. (like I just did with Elm) is download the Dash docset for it. The time it saves is extraordinary.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Got a weird diff report on a change in GitHub. Tracked it down to find it was a byte-order mark issue.

Thanks, Windows. I hate you.

Also, to be fair, Sublime Text 3 gets a little of my ire for changing the encoding on the fly. Don‚Äôt do that ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Y Combinators, how do they even work?
item.description: I was reading a post by Matt Might, a computer science professor at the University of Utah, about Y Combinators, and I was having a hard time tracking with some of it just by reading. The way I normally solve this problem is to write it out‚Äîand, optimally, to ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Lambda calculus. Church numerals.

This is my reading for a day when I feel terrible and just need to rest. I note and embrace the oddness.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I spent the afternoon modernizing a large chunk of Node.js code in preparation for fixing a bug‚Äîand I‚Äôve caught multiple other bugs along the way. (Also, my comfort level with JavaScript and functional programming has taken a massive leap since I originally wrote this!)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Testing Ember.js Mixins With a Container
item.description:
Today I was working on an Ember.js mixin for the new mobile web application we‚Äôre shipping at Olo, and I ran into an interesting problem when trying to test it.

When you‚Äôre testing mixins, you‚Äôre generally not working with the normal Ember container.1 In fact ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: When looking at an intimidatingly large software project, just ask: what is the very smallest thing I can build that is still useful? Once you have that, you can build on top of it, and you‚Äôll have momentum. You might rework it later, but that‚Äôs okay‚Äîyou‚Äôll ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: So I have a week off, and what have I spent this afternoon doing? Uhh‚Ä¶ working on some of my personal development tools, mostly. What can I say? It‚Äôs fun!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I originally posted this as a tweetstorm, but I‚Äôm treating this as the canonical and adding a tweet to the end of that ‚Äútopic‚Äù linking back here. Indie web forever.

item.description: Time zones: the bane of a software developer‚Äôs existence.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: P.S. I wrote that post on my iMac via SSH from an airplane somewhere over the Midwest. Crazy
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I needed to write a tiny server to test out some quirky single-page app stuff I‚Äôm doing for Olo right now. So I did it with Python and Flask.

And you know what? Python is still‚Äîand forever, I suspect‚Äîso much better than JavaScript.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Just bumped into another person who (quite reasonably) didn‚Äôt know that ES6 classes are just syntactic sugar for prototypes. I like classes‚Ä¶ but they‚Äôre more confusing than not, I think.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I just had one of thos beautiful moments when I realized I‚Äôd written a beautifully generic component I could reuse throughout the app, and it made me so happy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I think I‚Äôm sold on fish. The autocompletion alone is just delightful. Need to tweak it a bit, but even its defaults are pretty great.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: So, fish has some fascinating autocompletion. I may just have to play with it for a week and see if it lures me away from zsh.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I hate npm‚Äôs non-deterministic installs. Reproducible builds are essential, not optional.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I‚Äôve been working for a few weeks now on what has ended up being a much larger feature than I expected. CLOC tells me it‚Äôs a +1,320-lines-of-code change. But of those, 951 are tests. As it should be when writing JavaScript.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: After a few months of using Hasklig, reading code without code ligatures seems really weird to me.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Just finished a massive cleanup of about 4000 lines of an AngularJS codebase. It‚Äôs not amazing, but it‚Äôs a heck of a lot easier to deal with now.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I still love EmberJS‚Äîbut if I have one complaint, it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs slightly too heavy on convention-based magic. I want it to be a little more explicit, so that I can have a little more insight into what it‚Äôs going. Yes, even if that means a ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
On fire this morning: just knocking things out left and right.

I love Mondays. I‚Äôm well-rested, mentally fresh, and excited about the week.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
My Windows VM for work is now stuck in an endless cycle of reboots after a blue screen of death after an update.

Between that and its starting the update without asking me, I‚Äôm not feeling especially happy with Microsoft today.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Things I want basically all the time when writing JavaScript:

  • strong types
  • enums with values (tagged unions)
  • pattern-matching
  • immutability (more easily than with Object.freeze)
  • actual constants (not just fixed bindings like const)

Basically: an ML, I guess.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Betting I‚Äôm not the only one who thinks it a little weird that the Event.target in the DOM APIs is the source of the event.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: It is utterly infuriating how many parts of the DOM API are ‚Äúarray-like‚Äù but don‚Äôt have the basic Array API actually attached. Want to iterate over a HTMLCollection? You get to use a for loop with an index! Lucky you! üòê
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Oh. my. goodness.

How have I not used Emmet before? The experience is amazing. Mind. blown.

Good tools are good.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The more time I spend with languages with pattern matching and expressive type systems, the more I feel frustrated by things I just can‚Äôt express in JavaScript. If I could write Ember in something Elm‚Ä¶ I think I‚Äôd be giddy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: When you don‚Äôt know where to start on a programming issue, write some tests. You might throw them out and write different ones later, but the process will kick your brain into the right gear and you‚Äôll be moving along in no time. (Hat tip to Eric Farkas ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Why isn‚Äôt this updating? :looks around for five minutes: Oh. It‚Äôs because I‚Äôm just serving an old version, and don‚Äôt have it rebuilding as I make changes.

Yeah‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Oh, the difference between Friday afternoon and Monday morning, when trying to solve a problem. Spend two hours beating your head against a wall on Friday, or ten minutes on Monday morning. So it goes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Ulysses, Byword, and ‚ÄúJust Right‚Äù
item.description: I‚Äôm trying out Ulysses again, as it‚Äôs been updated substantially since I last used it. I think the main thing to say about it is that it‚Äôs gorgeous and a really great editor, and that there is nonetheless something about it which makes it feel not quite ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Throwing this out there: don‚Äôt organize your apps by ‚Äòkind of item‚Äô (view, controller, etc.). Organize by concern. A component‚Äôs template, controller, etc. should be right next to each other.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Well, paper-writing today may have pushed me to the breaking point. An app idea that‚Äôs been bubbling for months‚Ä¶ I think I‚Äôm going to start actually building pieces of it and learning for other bits this week.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Tip: if you get a very specific piece of feedback and have a standard workaround, it probably means you have a product design issue to fix.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Apparently, debugger; is a thing. My life would have been so much easier if I had known about this sooner than ten minutes ago.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Pro tip for tracking down oddities with Ember.js during testing: ember test --serve --filter '<some pattern>' is great. E.g. ember t -s --filter 'Unit' for just unit tests.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Pro tip: if you want to use Sublime Text with any project which has local node_modules, install something to ignore specified directories (e.g.¬†those in your gitignore) immediately. Same goes for anything with large, repeated builds (like Ember CLI). Yeesh.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Sites which rely on Adobe or Google Tag Manager for their basic functionality infuriate me. Stop. Just stop.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Seriously. All I want to do is transpile ES6 to ES5 and make it runnable in browser. And I need Browserify or Webpack for this? sigh
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Trying to do a little tweaking with the lightweight scripts I use on this site. Trying to automate things with Babel, browser imports, etc.

This is still far, far worse than it should be in 2016. Here‚Äôs hoping it‚Äôs (substantially!) better a year from now."
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
I ran into a Medium post arguing against ES6‚Äôs class implementation, and got linked to this argument against super(). Strongly concur.

Inheritance is fragile. Useful when appropriate, but fragile. Prefer composition.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The other day I posted about wanting to get my old joystick working on OS X, and thinking about writing drivers for it myself. Turns out I don‚Äôt need to, because ControllerMate is awesome.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Every time I do Node development, I conclude again‚Äîloudly‚Äîthat purely callback-driven APIs are incredibly annoying.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: If you‚Äôre contributing regularly to open source on GitHub, and you use the git command line at all, do yourself a favor and go install Hub right. now. Makes life so much easier.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: The Future of JavaScript
item.description: JavaScript (ECMAScript) is in a state of substantial change. And nearly all of those changes make our software development safer and more ergonomic! A short talk covering some of the biggest changes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I have an ongoing internal debate whether to hard-wrap lines in the source Markdown documents for my website (and everything else). Upside: it can be helpful when viewed in a terminal. Downside: it‚Äôs not very responsive in other editors or small phone views.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Static Site Generators and Podcasting
item.description: Presently, I publish both Winning Slowly and New Rustacean1 using what is admittedly a bit of a quirky approach. It works well for me, and I think it‚Äôs worth documenting for other nerdy types out there, but if you‚Äôre just getting going with podcasting and you‚Äôre ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Rust and Swift (xii)
item.description: I am reading through the Swift book, and comparing it to Rust, which I have also been learning over the past few months. As with the other posts in this series, these are off-the-cuff impressions, which may be inaccurate in various ways. I‚Äôd be happy to hear feedback! Note ‚Ä¶

item.description:
I posted these as a series of tweets.

Fired up and played the demo for Elite Dangerous on my Parallels VM. Made me want to buy it. But of course, I‚Äôd prefer to play it natively.

Of course, it‚Äôs available for Mac. But my (more than a decade ‚Ä¶

item.description: I have an irrational-but-ridiculously-strong desire to build an Atom package that is a tiny JavaScript wrapper around a Rust implementation. Just because.

item.description: I‚Äôm feeling the itch: to tweak both the information architecture and the visuals of this site. And maybe to use a different generator, since Pelican isn‚Äôt really up for the information architecture challenges I have.

item.description:
Reading Learn You a Haskell for Great Good.

Hang on‚Äîall name bindings are just functions? So many things just clicked. Mind. blown.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Looked at using Otto for dev environment management. I think it‚Äôll be great when it‚Äôs more mature; for right now, it‚Äôs too narrowly focused on Amazon, and plain-old Vagrant will do what I need better.

item.description: Of course, there‚Äôs another challenge with picking back up: I‚Äôve gotten spoiled by having ES2015 available and want to add it to this Angular project.

item.description: The upside to stepping away for a bit: I just found a bug in this code‚Ä¶ which I introduced in December 2014. :sigh:

item.description: It‚Äôs inevitably a bit challenging when you step away from a project for three months because of life and then come back to it and try to pick up where you previously left off.

item.description: I‚Äôm seriously thinking about trying Otto to make distinct environments for personal development projects.

item.description: Just noted a way my programming languages snobbery has increased: if you have nil/null/etc. instead of Maybe/Option/etc., I say NOPE NOPE NOPE.

item.description: Just bumped into ES6 static for the first time and was all what the heck?

Today I did a code review on my iPad while walking from school to a coffee shop, using my iPhone‚Äôs data connection as a hotspot.

What a world we live in.

item.description: Related to my previous post‚ÄîI really, really wish more of the fundamental papers on CS topics were freely available.

item.description: I‚Äôm suddenly finding myself with an interest in parsers and compilers. What is happening to me???

item.description: Inversion of control is a beautiful thing. Not least because it makes it so much easier to manage control over necessarily global state.

item.description: I find that I solve many software problems faster by writing them out with pen on paper. I wonder how common that is?

item.title: Rust and Swift (v)
item.description: I have been learning Rust and Swift in parallel. I wouldn‚Äôt normally recommend this course of action, but I‚Äôm finding it enormously profitable. You might, too, under the right circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: If-expressions in Rust
item.description:
I love the fact that all if statements in Rust are expressions. It gives you a great deal of expressitivity in the language.

Let‚Äôs contrast with Python (which I love, for the record). In Python, you can do something like this:

some_condition = True
if some_condition:
    a_value = "Yeah!"
else:
    a_value ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Needed to set up a simple test bed for a Python distribution with setuptools, which depends on external DLLs. So I used Rust and linked it up with Python‚Äôs FFI, because it was a perfect chance to see them interact.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: What are you using to track software development issues these days? JIRA, YouTrack, FogBugz, RedMine, or something else?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Flame war time: I‚Äôve basically concluded that for the tasks I use them for, I prefer Vim‚Äôs modal editing style to Emacs‚Äô not-modal editing style.

I‚Äôd still rather use Atom/Sublime or IntelliJ IDEA for almost everything, though.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Sometimes it is tempting as a designer to think that users are stupid. Don‚Äôt. If the software is not working for users, that implies stupidity in another party entirely: the one that designed the software. üòâ
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Ugh. I just discovered that a support email address has been sitting unattended for eight months. (Totally my fault.) Not a lot of problems‚Ä¶ but any unanswered emails for that long are the worst user experience. So frustrated with myself right now.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I‚Äôve been using Input for about ten days now. It grew on me slowly, but I really like it. Using it everywhere now!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: It turns out browsers render CSS transitions for positioning much more nicely than they do those for the box model (perhaps unsurprisingly, on reflection). Use position and top instead of margin to smoothly animate an item moving within its container.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: It‚Äôs nice when you evaluate a potential product‚Äôs market more closely and find your idea might actually be viable.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Where do you like to set your --prefix when configuring personal development tooling setups? Somewhere under ~? Or somewhere else?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: If you‚Äôre delivering images over the web, you need to be using something like ImageOptim. No excuses.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Tradeoffs time: whether ‚Äôtis better to drop in an off-the-shelf open source solution for this particular problem, and bring in all the extra weight it includes, or do it myself and pay in the time spent.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I can think of no more effective an argument for Rust and its memory safety guarantees than the time I spent this weekend hunting down bugs caused by buffer overruns in decades-old C code.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I found a CEditDlg instance and went looking for it in the MSDN docs, and was a bit nonplussed not to find it. Oh. It‚Äôs a CFileDialog subclass, and never mind the semantic ambiguity arising from the existence of a native CEdit class. üòê
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Thinking about setting Input as my typeface for doing my development for a week or two, see how it goes.

Anybody tried it? Bugs or problems to report?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Quote of the week (3-year-old Ellie talking to her mom, who has been learning Python): ‚ÄúMommy! I have a function for you!‚Äù
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Hooked up my digital piano to Logic Pro X tonight and wrote the theme for a podcast we‚Äôre doing together on learning to program. It‚Äôs so good!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Whoa! After years of demand, Confluence finally added support for importing Markdown-formatted content in its ‚ÄúMarkup‚Äù box. It‚Äôs not native support for editing in Markdown‚Ä¶ but it is a step forward. Good work, Atlassian.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Just recorded the first episode of a new, short, weekly podcast I‚Äôm working on. Audio should be live in about a week!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: People often point to this (hilariously accurate) flowchart to explain how to solve tech problems‚Ä¶ but it leaves something really important out: we ‚Äútechies‚Äù know the right questions to ask. That makes a big difference.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Another little feature of Rust I quite like: the use of traits instead of inheritance to share behavior. All the benefits of inheritance, and a few more besides, but none of the drawbacks.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I just realized that one of the reason Rust so strongly appeals to me is that its design embodies one of my favorite traits from the Zen of Python: explicit is better than implicit.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Courtesy of something in my stack not playing right, I‚Äôve now been reduced to pushing and pulling changes between OS X and my Windows VM through Bitbucket, rather than just having a mapped drive locally. This feels silly.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Hmm, this may be telling of the future‚Ä¶ SourceTree now introduces itself as a Git tool. No mention of Hg at all. üòü
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: My dear wife has started teaching herself Python as a hobby. She has the essential skill required to succeed as a programmer: the willingness to persevere even when it isn‚Äôt making sense to her. I‚Äôm extremely impressed.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Playing with CSS transforms and transitions while I listen to a lecture on Romans for my New Testament class. Keep myself awake‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I cannot wait till I can switch to ES2015. Got bit by the stupid var scoping issue again. You‚Äôd think I‚Äôd be past that by now‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
Reading JavaScript Allong√©. Just got to combinatorial logic (kestrel and idiot bird, for those in the know). Then he destructured a list with them.

Mind. Blown.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: One of the things that annoys me most when writing C is how difficult (really, almost impossible) it is to do anything generically. The same operation for different items in a struct? Good luck. It‚Äôs possible, but rarely worth the work.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: HTML5 Location, <base>, and SVG
item.description: Angular requires if you want to use HTML5's location‚Ä¶ but if you get it wrong, SVG things can and will break under you.

item.description: To my great delight, and thanks to a suggestion from App.net friend @jnm, I was able to get a static copy of my 2012‚Äì2013-era site archived this evening. That in turn means I‚Äôll be able to replace my WordPress install with static HTML pages over the next ‚Ä¶

item.title: How to Build a Single-Page App API Right
item.description: How to write a single-page app API so that you get usable data on the first load *and* have a nice interface for your single-page application built in Ember/Angular/Knockout/Backbone/etc.

item.description: Tip: if you‚Äôre using Mercurial‚Äôs bookmarks to track lightweight branches, somewhat analogous to Git‚Äôs branches, use Mercurial‚Äôs special @ tag to track whatever you want to treat as the tip of a master branch. That way, any clone will check that out by default.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I just taught Jaimie how to use GitHub for Mac (as she is helping a friend with his Jekyll-powered website), and explained the basics of distributed version control. She is totally a boss. And GitHub for Mac is a pretty good app.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
One of (many) irritations with using Angular: every search turns up Bootstrap solutions.

I‚Äôm not using Bootstrap.

:sigh:

item.description: That project I started on the other day? It‚Äôs still going‚Ä¶ and swimmingly. I‚Äôve now gotten it not only working at the most basic level (as it was before) but also to do a bit more complex work. You can see it (and any other scripts I build ‚Ä¶

item.description: Currently on my mind: how to chunk up the Bible text with semantic blobs and chapter/verse trees in corresponding data structures, in order to present meaningful sections of content (paragraphs, etc.) without resorting to delivering a whole book.

item.description: This post brought to you by a brand new script, which automatically generates the file needed‚ÄîYAML header and all!‚Äîto create a new microblog post on chriskrycho.com. Python for the win.

item.title: Open Source is Neat

item.description: Updated the websites today. Did a bunch of back end work that should be basically invisible or make a change seamlessly on the front end for both chriskrycho.com and winningslowly.org. Very satisfying day; nice to be working on things just because I can.

item.title: Lessons Learned

item.title: Unsurprisingly, In Flux
item.description: The state of JavaScript frameworks today is a scale, really, from not-at-all-monolithic to totally-monolithic, in roughly this order: Backbone ‚Äì React & Angular ‚Äì Ember ‚Äì Meteor.

item.title: The Joy of Good Tools
item.description: I started out with a post on being willing to pay for GitHub. I ended up with a meditation on vocation and delight. It's quite the journey!

item.title: Growing Up Together

item.title: Pushing Into C's Corner Cases
item.description: I‚Äôm working on a project that is all in C because of its long history and legacy. We‚Äôre slowly modernizing the codebase and writing all our new code in Python (using NumPy, C extensions, and so on for performance where necessary). Occasionally, I just want to bang my ‚Ä¶

item.title: The Long Race
item.description: It has been too long since I have written anything‚Äîtoo long not for my audience (small as it is), but for my soul. The last few weeks of class were of course even busier than the rest of the semester, courtesy of a couple major assignments I wrapped up ‚Ä¶

item.title: Learning QML, Part 1
item.description: For part of my work with Quest Consultants, I‚Äôve been picking up Qt‚Äôs QML toolkit to use in building out the UI. The declarative syntax and ability to define one‚Äôs own model in non-C++- or Python-specific ways is quite nice. That said, the learning process has had ‚Ä¶

item.title: Feels Right
item.description: Little details in how things work can make all the difference when it comes to the experience of using software. So be diligent, and do it right.

item.title: FirebirdSQL and IntelliJ IDEA (etc.)
item.description: Configuration instructions for FirebirdSQL JDBC with JetBrains IntelliJ IDEA platform (including PyCharm, RubyMine, WebStorm, etc.).

item.title: Doing It Myself
item.description: Working with Pelican—the static site generator I use for my blog currently—has reinforced my desire to write my own such software. Sometimes, you just have to do it yourself.
